Translator: Emile Dingemans
Reviewer: Rik Delaet

8.text:
Every day we engage in a behavior
that is completely contrary

12.text: to how we would optimally function.

14.text:
And I'm not talking
about a modern technological practice

18.text:
such as posting embarrassing snapshots
of one's unsuspecting partner on Facebook.

24.text:
I'm talking about
an integral human behavior.

27.text:
I'm talking about
a deeply intimate behavior.

31.text:
Every day we engage
in a behavior that requires us

34.text: to distort our thoughts, numb our feelings

37.text: and act against our core values,

40.text: and which enables a global atrocity

43.text:
that can make even the most stoic
of us weep in sorrow.

47.text:
And every day we could choose
not to engage in this behavior,

51.text:
except we don't realize
that it's irrational.

55.text:
We don't see that it's destructive
and we don't even know we have a choice.

61.text:
How can some of the most frequent
and important choices we make,

66.text: appear not to be choices at all?

69.text:
How can the irrationality and destruction
of a widespread behavior

76.text:
These are the questions I asked when I
began my nearly two decades of research

80.text: on the psychology of eating animals.

82.text:
And what I discovered was
not at all what I had expected.

86.text:
As it turns out,
there's a distinct underlying factor

90.text:
that both drives our behavior
and prevents us

94.text:
from recognizing its irrationality
and the destruction it causes.

98.text: I identified and codified this factor

100.text:
and I'm here to share
my findings with you.

103.text:
And the good news is that simply
becoming aware of this factor

107.text:
enables us to reclaim our rationality
and freedom of choice

110.text:
and become more active participants in
creating a humane and just world.

116.text: My journey of discovery began in 1968,

120.text:
25 years before I set foot
in my first Harvard lecture.

126.text:
I received the Ahimsa Award
at the British House of Commons

129.text: for my work on global non-violence.

138.text: My family adopted a puppy we named Fritz.

140.text:
Now, Fritz was my first dog and
he was also my first friend.

146.text:
We played together.
We napped together.

149.text:
And we even vomited together
once during a sickening road trip.

155.text: And Fritz was also my first heartbreak

157.text:
when he died at the age of 13
of liver cancer.

161.text:
What I didn't realize back then
was that my connection with Fritz

164.text:
would lead to a discovery
that would transform my worldview.

169.text:
So I cared about Fritz
and I'm not unique.

172.text: Most of us care about animals.

175.text:
We teach our children
to be kind to animals.

178.text:
Our hearts leap
when we witness them at play.

181.text:
We recognize the injustice and feel
outraged when they are abused.

188.text:
We share their fear,
their joy, their sorrow.

193.text:
And how many of you have cared
about a certain animal in your life?

201.text: That's a whole lot of caring.

204.text:
So to explain how
my connection with my dog

207.text:
led me to this stage,
I'd like to do a thought experiment.

211.text:
Imagine that you're a guest
at a dinner party

214.text:
and your host serves you
a dish that looks like this.

219.text:
Consider whether you find
this delicious or disgusting.

223.text: For those who would find it delicious,

225.text:
imagine you find it so delicious
that you ask your host for the recipe.

229.text: And she replies the secret is in the meat.

232.text: You use three pounds of well-seasoned -

242.text:
Now take a moment to reflect
on your thoughts and feelings.

245.text:
Chances are, what you had
just thought of as food,

248.text: you now think of as a dead animal.

251.text:
What you just felt was delicious,
you now feel is disgusting.

254.text:
Chances are, your experience
of the meat dramatically changed.

258.text:
Even though nothing about the meat
itself actually changed.

265.text:
Well, what changed
is your perception of the meat.

268.text:
When it comes to eating animals
our perception is shaped

272.text: largely, if not entirely, by our culture.

275.text: In meat-eating cultures around the world,

278.text: out of over seven million animal species,

281.text:
people tend to classify
only a handful as edible.

284.text:
All the rest are inedible
and disgusting.

289.text:
So the question is,
why are we not disgusted

293.text:
by the select species we have learned
to think of as edible?

297.text: And why don't we ever ask why?

303.text:
Have you ever wondered why you might
eat certain animals but not others?

308.text:
Have you ever wondered
why you haven't wondered?

312.text:
For much of my life I never wondered
about my choice to eat certain animals

316.text: because I never even knew I had a choice.

319.text:
No one had ever asked me
if I believed in eating animals.

323.text: Eating animals was just a given.

326.text:
So, I never thought about
how strange it was

329.text:
that I could pet my dog with one hand,
while I ate a pork chop with the other.

335.text: A pork chop that had once been an animal

338.text:
who was at least as sentient
and intelligent as my dog.

342.text:
And frankly I didn't want to think
about this contradiction;

345.text: it was just easier not to.

349.text:
It wasn't until 1989
that I started asking why.

353.text:
I had been hospitalized after eating
what would be my very last hamburger.

358.text:
A burger that was contaminated
with the dangerous bacteria Campylobacter.

363.text: After being so sick I swore off meat.

372.text:
When I stopped eating animals
I had a paradigm shift.

377.text:
In other words,
I didn't see different things,

381.text: I saw the same things differently.

385.text:
Beef stew seemed no different
than golden retriever stew.

389.text:
And everywhere I turned I saw people
putting the bodies of dead animals

393.text:
into their mouth as though
nothing at all were wrong.

397.text:
So I became very curious as to how
rational caring people, like myself,

403.text: could just stop thinking and feeling.

408.text:
Well, two advanced degrees later,
I had my answer.

412.text: And this is what I discovered:

416.text:
There is an invisible
belief system or ideology

420.text: that conditions us to eat certain animals.

423.text: And I named the system: Carnism.

428.text:
We tend to assume that only vegans and
vegetarians follow a belief system.

433.text: But when eating animals is not a necessity

437.text:
- which is the case
in much of the world today -

441.text: And choices always stem from beliefs.

445.text: Now carnism is a dominant ideology.

452.text:
its doctrine is seen as a given
rather than a choice.

455.text: Eating animals is just the way things are.

459.text: And it is a violent ideology.

463.text: Meat cannot be procured without violence.

466.text:
And egg and dairy production cause
extensive harm to animals.

470.text:
Ideologies such as carnism
run counter to core human values.

476.text:
Values such as compassion,
justice and authenticity.

482.text:
And so they need
to use defense mechanisms

485.text:
that distort our thoughts
and numb our feelings

489.text:
so that we act against our values
without fully realizing what we are doing.

497.text:
Now, the main defense
of carnism is denial,

500.text:
which is expressed largely
through invisibility.

508.text:
For instance, 1.2 billion farmed animals
are slaughtered globally every week.

516.text:
So in one week
more farmed animals are killed

520.text:
than the total number of people killed
in all wars throughout history.

527.text:
But how many of these animals
have you seen?

533.text:
Approximately 98 percent of the meat,
eggs and dairy we eat

538.text:
comes from animals
who were raised in factory farms.

544.text:
that are virtually impossible
to obtain access to.

547.text:
Yet, although these animals
are treated as commodities,

552.text:
they are in fact sentient,
intelligent individuals

555.text: with lives that matter to them.

558.text:
In a moment I'm going
to show a two-minute video

562.text:
of animal factories
which can be difficult to watch.

565.text:
So I want to remind you that my intention
is simply to raise awareness.

570.text: So I have to make the invisible visible.

573.text:
I've selected material that I think
is sufficient to inform you,

579.text:
But if it's too difficult to watch,
just close your eyes and plug your ears.

587.text:
Piglets are castrated by workers
who cut into their skin

594.text: Next the workers chop off their tail.

597.text:
Once pigs have reached market weight,
they are sent to slaughter.

600.text:
At the slaughterhouse pigs are knocked
in the head with a steal rod,

604.text:
hung upside down
and have their throats slit.

613.text:
to having their throats slit while
they are fully conscious and suffering.

619.text: Because male chicks don't lay eggs,

621.text:
and do not grow quickly enough
to be raised profitably for meat,

624.text:
they are killed
within hours after hatching.

628.text: The females have it even worse.

630.text:
Workers use a hot blade or laser
to remove part of the chicks' beaks.

637.text:
At the slaughter plant,
the birds are dumped from their crates,

642.text:
into moving shackles
by their fragile legs.

645.text:
They are then pulled across a blade
which slices their throats

649.text: causing blood to pour from their necks.

652.text:
Calves on dairy farms are dragged away
from their mothers and violently killed.

660.text:
The majority of today's dairy cows
are confined on factory farms.

665.text:
Workers subject young cows
to painful mutilations and amputations.

673.text:
Unreliable stunning practices
at the slaughterhouse

675.text:
condemn many cattle
to having their throats cut,

679.text:
their limps hacked off
while still alive and conscious.

685.text:
Massive trawling nets
indiscriminately drag hundreds of tons

689.text:
of fish and other animals
along the ocean floor.

692.text: They are then tossed on board,

694.text:
where the surviving fish either suffocate
or are crushed to death.

701.text: I know it can be painful to see that.

704.text: Fortunately for us the hard part is over.

707.text:
But before we move on
I want to just point out

710.text:
that this footage focuses
on standard industry practices

714.text:
including in so-called humane
or bio facilities.

718.text:
And I also want to point out
that there is a gift in our pain.

724.text:
Our pain is the mirror in which we can see
the reflection of our humanity.

732.text:
So, clearly the animals pay
for our carnism.

736.text: But we are also victims of the system.

739.text: We pay for our carnism with our health,

742.text:
as eating an animal-based diet
can lead to serious disease,

746.text:
while eating a plant-based or vegan diet
can optimize health.

751.text:
And we pay for our carnism
with our hearts and with our minds,

756.text:
with our dampened empathy
and diminished objectivity.

763.text:
But, of course, invisibility alone
cannot maintain the system.

766.text: Hints of the truth surround us.

773.text:
And the way that we learn to justify
eating animals is by learning to believe

777.text:
that the myths of meat, eggs and dairy
are the facts of meat, eggs and dairy.

782.text:
These myths are expressed
largely through what I refer to as:

788.text:
Eating animals is -
What do you think?

801.text:
And haven't we heard
this somewhere before?

806.text: Slavery is normal, natural and necessary.

810.text:
Male dominance is normal,
natural and necessary.

814.text:
Heterosexual supremacy
is normal, natural and necessary.

821.text:
And as with other
dominant violent ideologies,

824.text:
the myths of carnism
are institutionalized.

827.text:
So carnistic bias is embedded
within the very foundations of the system.

835.text:
And when we are born into an
institutionalized system, such as carnism,

842.text:
we learn to look at the world
through the lens of carnism.

847.text: And carnism uses a set of defenses

849.text:
that distort our perceptions
of farmed animals.

852.text:
For instance, carnism teaches us to see
farmed animals as abstractions,

857.text:
as lacking any individuality or
personality of their own.

862.text:
A pig is a pig and
all pigs are the same.

867.text:
And carnism blinds us
to the absurdities of the system.

876.text:
If we believe absurdities,
we shall commit atrocities.

881.text:
And carnism is but one
of the many atrocities,

885.text: one of the many violent ideologies,

887.text:
that are an unfortunate part
of the human legacy.

889.text:
And although the experience
of each set of victims

893.text:
will always be somewhat unique,
the ideologies themselves are similar,

898.text:
the mentality that enables
such violence is the same.

903.text:
It's the mentality of domination
and subjugation.

912.text:
It's the mentality that causes us
to turn someone into something,

916.text: to reduce a life to a unit of production.

924.text:
that makes us feel entitled to wield
complete control over the lives and deaths

929.text:
of those with less power -
just because we can.

934.text: And to feel justified in our actions

943.text: It is the mentality of meat.

948.text:
And so if we fail to pick out
the common threads

951.text:
that are woven through
all violent ideologies,

954.text:
then we will recreate
atrocities in new forms.

957.text:
But if we identify
these common threads,

960.text:
then we can unravel atrocities
in all forms.

966.text:
And so, this brings us
to our final question.

972.text:
How can we lead more authentic
and freely chosen lives

975.text:
and bring our optimal selves
into the world?

979.text:
Well, it turns out the solution
is already in our grasp.

983.text:
Seventeen minutes ago you may not
have been aware of carnism,

986.text: the invisible ideology that disconnects us

989.text:
from our rationality,
our feelings and our values.

992.text:
And which enables
a massive global injustice.

1002.text:
Your awareness is
the first step of the solution.

1008.text:
And acting from your awareness
is the rest.

1013.text:
And awareness has always been
the antidote to violent ideologies.

1017.text: Virtually every atrocity was made possible

1021.text:
because the populace
turned away from a reality,

1024.text: they felt was too painful to face.

1029.text:
every social transformation,
was made possible

1032.text: because of those who chose awareness

1035.text: and who acted on what they had learned.

1041.text:
And the good news is that there is
an alternative to carnism.

1046.text:
The vegan movement,
which is the counterpoint to carnism,

1049.text: is one of the fastest growing

1051.text:
social justice movements
in the world today.

1054.text:
And the good news is also
that we can make minor changes

1058.text: that will have a major impact.

1060.text:
We can reduce and ultimately eliminate
our consumption of meat, eggs and dairy.

1065.text:
To start, we can eat
just one vegan meal a day,

1069.text: or one vegan day a week.

1071.text: And we can spread carnism awareness,

1074.text:
which is the mission
of my organization: Beyond Carnism.

1079.text:
If each of us shares this talk
with everyone we know,

1084.text:
carnism awareness will inevitably
reach critical mass,

1088.text:
and will bring about
a global paradigm shift.

1093.text:
So we have the potential
to change the world,

1098.text:
if you believe that carnism awareness
is an idea worth spreading.
